Deviation blog feedhttp://deviation.nodejitsu.comAll the posts from the Deviation blog. Windows installation of node-canvas http://deviation.nodejitsu.com/blog/view/6vhmuvia8hd34l7i5ygxitzot46kdh5a

After what seemed like decades trying to get node-canvas to work on my x64 Windows 7 development box, success! Here's the process I used:

npm

Make sure npm is installed and up-to-date.

> node cli.js install npm -gf

> npm update -g npm

node-gyp

node-gyp is a build tool.

  1. Install Python 2.7.2. Version 3 is not yet supported.
  2. Install Microsoft Visual C++ Express if you don't have the full version.
  3. For 64-bit builds of node and native modules you will also need the Windows 7 64-bit SDK.

> npm install -g node-gyp

It very important that you reboot the machine after these installations.

node-canvas

  1. Download the all-in-one GTK bundle and unzip it to c:\GTK (modifying the binding.gyp file if this changes).
  2. Download the node-canvas zip file and put it in the node_modules folder 'canvas'.
  3. Command in to the canvas folder and run:

> node-gyp configure

  1. Copy all the dll files from c:\GTK to the canvas\build\Release folder.
  2. Copy IEShims.dll from c:\program files(x86)\Internet Explorer to the canvas\build\Release folder

> node-gyp build

This will build the canvas.node object. If the node engine still doesn't recognise it, use the Dependancy Walker to inspect the canvas.node object to see what dlls are missing. Add those dlls to the canvas\build\Release folder and re-run the process.

In addition, having used this process to build canvas, you can also build d3.js without fail.

Spotmaps

The Spotmap project is almost complete. After a couple of months finagling with the Python code doing stupid things with classes and modules, I ejected all the code and went back to the original one-file process because it was just getting too ridiculous by far to keep track of the changes. That left the server implementation which, in the end, I decided to code up in javascript via nodeJS. Which meant I had to learn the how-tos and wherefores of nodeJS as quickly as possible.

Blog

Considering the route for my blog is to hold all posts in memory for quick load times and filtering. I might hold off on this as loading at browser reset is a little easier in Development, and with one screen of text < 2k this isn't posing a problem or a slowdown.

Kanban scheduler

This is new. See http://www.simple-kanban.com/ for more details.

Or, more to the point, Scrum-ban (Kana-scrum?).

Posts -> Images

Sort of a steganography exercise, coding blog posts into canvas images using the hex equivalent of ascii characters to produce RGB values. You can see the results at the top of each post - the blocky image that's been opacitied to hell. The neat thing about it is that it doesn't just store the text of the post, it stores the JSON post object in its entirety.

At the moment the image size is 50 spots per row, and each spot is 2 pixels square. Already you can see the space that has been saved. Changing the spot size and the canvas width should provide us with some great sampling opportunities once more posts are written, although I do need to sort out a better colour algorithm.\n\nBy the way, the main data in the post is written in markdown and converted to HTML on the fly.
